caption.p: Bio-activity of nanoparticles synthesized using Terminalia sp. extracts.

tr.td: Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark
TA-AgNPs inhibited E. coli, while the extract exhibited non-effects on the organism.
Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. leaf
TA-AuNPs induces the mitotic cell division and pollen germination. TA-AuNPs showed a non-cytotoxic effect on Allium cepa root tip cells and Gloriosa superba pollen grains.
TB-AgNPs at 120 μg/mL killed 69.1% colon cancer cells and 65.2% breast cancer cells. The TB-AgNPs did not cause cytotoxic effects against normal cardiac and skeletal muscle cells.
Copper nanoparticles (TM-CuONPs), Iron nanoparticles (TM-FeONPs), Zinc nanoparticles (TM-ZnONPs).
Inhibition zone of TM-CuONPs, TM-FeONPs, and TM-ZnONPs against Staphylococcus aureus ranged from 22–24 mM.

TC-AgNPs showed antibacterial activity against both S. aureus and E. coli. Nylon cloth-TC-AgNPs exhibited antibacterial activity against the organisms with a strength of 3 to 13 times greater than TC-AgNPs.
The antibacterial activity of TC-AuNPs against Gram-positive S. aureus was better than Gram-negative E. coli measured by the well diffusion method.
MIC values of the TM-AgNPs (3.12 µg/mL) were 40 times lower than those of the extract (125 µg/mL).
Terminali arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark extract

Co-administration with green synthesized AuNPs with size ranging between 20 and 40 nM along with acetaminophen showed effective significant recovery in the hematological alterations of male Wistar rats.
Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark extract

The TA-PdNPs were utilized as an efficient catalyst for Heck and Suzuki type C-C coupling reactions and degradation of organic dyes in aqueous medium making it useful in synthetic organic chemistry and the removal of toxic industrial pollutants, respectively.
Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark extract
AgNPs were spherical in shape ranges with 40–50 nM in size. These nanoparticles showed the inhibition of Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria.

AuNPs were spherical shape ranges with 20–30 nM and found to be effective against Candida tropicalis and Candida albicans isolated from clinical samples. AuNPs also effectively worked as free radical scavenging activity.
Termanilia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark extract
Metal oxide nanoparticles: Copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) and Zinc nanoparticles (ZnNPs)

CuNPs exhibited maximum antibacterial efficacy than ZnNPs against the entire organism tested. K. pneumoniae showed high resistance to both the biosynthesized nanoparticles. CuNPs exhibited maximum efficacy when compared to ZNPs in antihemolytic activity against hypotonic and heat-induced hemolysis of erythrocytes.
Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. leaf extracts

AuNPs were treated with two different concentrations (500 and 1,000 μM) of Gloriosa superba seeds. Au NPs exposure at 1,000 μM concentration has the most significant effect on seed germination rate and vegetative growth of G. superba. This is the first report on Au NPs as a biocompatibility material to enhance the seed yield of this endangered medicinal plant.
Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn. bark extract
The in vitro antimicrobial activity was found to be effective for CuNPs dried at room temperature when compared to CuNPs dried at 70°C. From this study, CuNPs shows a very good antioxidant property.

Terminalia catappa L. (TC) leaf extract was treated with chloroauric acid solutions, showing a rapid reduction of chloroaurate ions leading to the formation of highly stable AuNPs in solution. AuNPs (10–35 nM size; average size 21.9 nM) can be used as the reducing and stabilizing agent.
